Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 18, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
A 13,000 mile dragon of earth and stone winds its way through
the countryside of China with a history almost as long
and serpentine as the structure. The Great Wall began as multiple walls
of rammed earth built by individual feudal states
during the Chunqiu period to protect against nomadic raiders
north of China and each other. When Emperor Qin Shi Huang
unified the states in 221 BCE, the Tibetan Plateau and Pacific Ocean
became natural barriers, but the mountains in the north
remained vulnerable to Mongol, Turkish, and Xiongnu invasions. To defend against them, the Emperor expanded the small walls
built by his predecessors, connecting some and fortifying others. As the structures grew
from Lintao in the west to Liaodong in the east, they collectively became known
as The Long Wall. To accomplish this task, the Emperor enlisted soldiers
and commoners, not always voluntarily. Of the hundreds of thousands of builders
recorded during the Qin Dynasty, many were forcibly conscripted peasants and others were criminals
serving out sentences. Under the Han Dynasty,
the wall grew longer still, reaching 3700 miles, and spanning from Dunhuang
to the Bohai Sea. Forced labor continued
under the Han Emperor Han-Wudi , and the walls reputation grew
into a notorious place of suffering. Poems and legends of the time
told of laborers buried in nearby mass graves, or even within the wall itself. And while no human remains
have been found inside, grave pits do indicate
that many workers died from accidents, hunger and exhaustion. The wall was formidable
but not invincible. Both Genghis and his son Khublai Khan
managed to surmount the wall during the Mongol invasion
of the 13th Century. After the Ming dynasty
gained control in 1368, they began to refortify
and further consolidate the wall using bricks and stones from local kilns. Averaging 23 feet high and 21 feet wide, the walls 5500 miles
were punctuated by watchtowers. When raiders were sighted, fire and smoke signals traveled
between towers until reinforcements arrived. Small openings along the wall
let archers fire on invaders, while larger ones were used
to drop stones and more. But even this new and improved wall
was not enough. In 1644, northern Manchu clans
overthrew the Ming to establish the Qing dynasty, incorporating Mongolia as well, Thus, for the second time, China was ruled by the very people
the wall had tried to keep out. With the empire's borders
now extending beyond the Great Wall, the fortifications lost their purpose. And without regular reinforcement,
the wall fell into disrepair, rammed earth eroded, while brick and stone were plundered
for building materials. But its job wasn't finished. During World War II, China used sections for defense
against Japanese invasion, and some parts are still rumored
to be used for military training. But the Wall's main purpose
today is cultural. As one of the largest man-made
structures on Earth, it was granted UNESCO
World Heritage Status in 1987. Originally built to keep
people out of China, the Great Wall now welcomes
millions of visitors each year. In fact, the influx of tourists
has caused the wall to deteriorate, leading the Chinese government
to launch preservation initiatives. It's also often acclaimed as the only
man-made structure visible from space. Unfortunately, that's not at all true. In low Earth orbit,
all sorts of structures, like bridges, highways
and airports are visible, and the Great Wall
is only barely discernible. From the moon, it doesn't stand a chance. But regardless, it's the Earth
we should be studying it from because new sections
are still discovered every few years, branching off from the main body and expanding this remarkable
monument to human achievement.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: True or false: The Great Wall is one long wall that spans 100,000 miles.
Options: A. True, B. False
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What type of pronoun is "I" in a sentence? Options: A. Object pronoun, B. Subject pronoun, C. Reflexive pronoun, D. Intensive pronoun Correct Option: B
Question 2: Which of the following sentences demonstrates the difference between a subject and an object in a sentence? Options: A. "I invited her, but she invited I.", B. "I invited her, but she invited me.", C. "She danced around me, while he shimmied up to me.", D. "Me heard gossip." Correct Option: B
Question 3: What is the main function of "myself" in a sentence? Options: A. To act as a subject pronoun, B. To act as an object pronoun, C. To add emphasis, D. To act as a reflexive pronoun Correct Option: D
Question 4: In the sentence "Please tell Jack or myself," which of the following is the correct pronoun to use? Options: A. I, B. Me, C. Myself, D. They Correct Option: B
Question 5: In which of the following sentences is "myself" used as an intensive pronoun? Options: A. "I consider myself the most important pronoun at this year's party.", B. "Myself heard gossip.", C. "I, myself, have heard others agree.", D. "Me heard gossip." Correct Option: C
Question 6: What is the main difference between "me" and "I" in a sentence? Options: A. "Me" is used for formal writing, while "I" is used for informal writing., B. "Me" is used as a subject pronoun, while "I" is used as an object pronoun., C. "Me" is used as an object pronoun, while "I" is used as a subject pronoun., D. "Me" is used as a reflexive pronoun, while "I" is used as an intensive pronoun. Correct Option: C
Question 7: How can you determine whether to use "I" or "me" in a sentence? Options: A. By temporarily eliminating the other person in the sentence., B. By using a dictionary to look up the definition of the word., C. By using a thesaurus to find a synonym for the word., D. By using a grammar book to look up the rule. Correct Option: A
Question 8: What is the main function of "myself" in the sentence "I consider myself the most important pronoun at this year's party"? Options: A. To add emphasis, B. To act as a subject pronoun, C. To act as an object pronoun, D. To act as a reflexive pronoun Correct Option: D
Question 9: Which of the following sentences is an example of a sentence that uses "myself" as a reflexive pronoun? Options: A. "Myself heard gossip.", B. "I consider myself the most important pronoun at this year's party.", C. "Myself is going to the store.", D. "I, myself, have heard others agree." Correct Option: B
Question 10: What is the main idea of the transcript? Options: A. To explain the difference between "me" and "I" in a sentence., B. To explain the difference between "myself" and "me" in a sentence., C. To explain how to use "myself" in a sentence., D. To explain the main functions of pronouns in a sentence. Correct Option: D

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 18, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
A 13,000 mile dragon of earth and stone winds its way through
the countryside of China with a history almost as long
and serpentine as the structure. The Great Wall began as multiple walls
of rammed earth built by individual feudal states
during the Chunqiu period to protect against nomadic raiders
north of China and each other. When Emperor Qin Shi Huang
unified the states in 221 BCE, the Tibetan Plateau and Pacific Ocean
became natural barriers, but the mountains in the north
remained vulnerable to Mongol, Turkish, and Xiongnu invasions. To defend against them, the Emperor expanded the small walls
built by his predecessors, connecting some and fortifying others. As the structures grew
from Lintao in the west to Liaodong in the east, they collectively became known
as The Long Wall. To accomplish this task, the Emperor enlisted soldiers
and commoners, not always voluntarily. Of the hundreds of thousands of builders
recorded during the Qin Dynasty, many were forcibly conscripted peasants and others were criminals
serving out sentences. Under the Han Dynasty,
the wall grew longer still, reaching 3700 miles, and spanning from Dunhuang
to the Bohai Sea. Forced labor continued
under the Han Emperor Han-Wudi , and the walls reputation grew
into a notorious place of suffering. Poems and legends of the time
told of laborers buried in nearby mass graves, or even within the wall itself. And while no human remains
have been found inside, grave pits do indicate
that many workers died from accidents, hunger and exhaustion. The wall was formidable
but not invincible. Both Genghis and his son Khublai Khan
managed to surmount the wall during the Mongol invasion
of the 13th Century. After the Ming dynasty
gained control in 1368, they began to refortify
and further consolidate the wall using bricks and stones from local kilns. Averaging 23 feet high and 21 feet wide, the walls 5500 miles
were punctuated by watchtowers. When raiders were sighted, fire and smoke signals traveled
between towers until reinforcements arrived. Small openings along the wall
let archers fire on invaders, while larger ones were used
to drop stones and more. But even this new and improved wall
was not enough. In 1644, northern Manchu clans
overthrew the Ming to establish the Qing dynasty, incorporating Mongolia as well, Thus, for the second time, China was ruled by the very people
the wall had tried to keep out. With the empire's borders
now extending beyond the Great Wall, the fortifications lost their purpose. And without regular reinforcement,
the wall fell into disrepair, rammed earth eroded, while brick and stone were plundered
for building materials. But its job wasn't finished. During World War II, China used sections for defense
against Japanese invasion, and some parts are still rumored
to be used for military training. But the Wall's main purpose
today is cultural. As one of the largest man-made
structures on Earth, it was granted UNESCO
World Heritage Status in 1987. Originally built to keep
people out of China, the Great Wall now welcomes
millions of visitors each year. In fact, the influx of tourists
has caused the wall to deteriorate, leading the Chinese government
to launch preservation initiatives. It's also often acclaimed as the only
man-made structure visible from space. Unfortunately, that's not at all true. In low Earth orbit,
all sorts of structures, like bridges, highways
and airports are visible, and the Great Wall
is only barely discernible. From the moon, it doesn't stand a chance. But regardless, it's the Earth
we should be studying it from because new sections
are still discovered every few years, branching off from the main body and expanding this remarkable
monument to human achievement.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Which emperor first consolidated the many walls into what became known as the "Long Wall"?
Options: A. Emperor Qianglong, B. Emperor Qin Shi Huang, C. Emperor Han Wudi
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What type of pronoun is "I" in a sentence? Options: A. Object pronoun, B. Subject pronoun, C. Reflexive pronoun, D. Intensive pronoun Correct Option: B
Question 2: Which of the following sentences demonstrates the difference between a subject and an object in a sentence? Options: A. "I invited her, but she invited I.", B. "I invited her, but she invited me.", C. "She danced around me, while he shimmied up to me.", D. "Me heard gossip." Correct Option: B
Question 3: What is the main function of "myself" in a sentence? Options: A. To act as a subject pronoun, B. To act as an object pronoun, C. To add emphasis, D. To act as a reflexive pronoun Correct Option: D
Question 4: In the sentence "Please tell Jack or myself," which of the following is the correct pronoun to use? Options: A. I, B. Me, C. Myself, D. They Correct Option: B
Question 5: In which of the following sentences is "myself" used as an intensive pronoun? Options: A. "I consider myself the most important pronoun at this year's party.", B. "Myself heard gossip.", C. "I, myself, have heard others agree.", D. "Me heard gossip." Correct Option: C
Question 6: What is the main difference between "me" and "I" in a sentence? Options: A. "Me" is used for formal writing, while "I" is used for informal writing., B. "Me" is used as a subject pronoun, while "I" is used as an object pronoun., C. "Me" is used as an object pronoun, while "I" is used as a subject pronoun., D. "Me" is used as a reflexive pronoun, while "I" is used as an intensive pronoun. Correct Option: C
Question 7: How can you determine whether to use "I" or "me" in a sentence? Options: A. By temporarily eliminating the other person in the sentence., B. By using a dictionary to look up the definition of the word., C. By using a thesaurus to find a synonym for the word., D. By using a grammar book to look up the rule. Correct Option: A
Question 8: What is the main function of "myself" in the sentence "I consider myself the most important pronoun at this year's party"? Options: A. To add emphasis, B. To act as a subject pronoun, C. To act as an object pronoun, D. To act as a reflexive pronoun Correct Option: D
Question 9: Which of the following sentences is an example of a sentence that uses "myself" as a reflexive pronoun? Options: A. "Myself heard gossip.", B. "I consider myself the most important pronoun at this year's party.", C. "Myself is going to the store.", D. "I, myself, have heard others agree." Correct Option: B
Question 10: What is the main idea of the transcript? Options: A. To explain the difference between "me" and "I" in a sentence., B. To explain the difference between "myself" and "me" in a sentence., C. To explain how to use "myself" in a sentence., D. To explain the main functions of pronouns in a sentence. Correct Option: D


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
Unfortunately, none of the generated MCQs match the ground truth MCQ in terms of question intent, options, and content. The generated MCQs appear to be related to grammar and pronouns, while the ground truth MCQ is about the Great Wall of China and the emperor who consolidated the many walls into what became known as the "Long Wall".

However, I can suggest that the generated MCQs do not match the ground truth MCQ, and it would be best to generate new MCQs that are relevant to the transcript and the ground truth MCQ.

If I had to choose an index, I would say that none of the generated MCQs match, but if I had to select one, I would say -1 or "Not Applicable" as an index, as none of the generated MCQs are relevant to the ground truth MCQ.

However, I can also suggest that Question 10 is the only one that is slightly relevant to the transcript, but it does not match the ground truth MCQ in terms of question intent, options, and content.

So, the index of the most similar generated MCQ would be "Not Applicable" or -1, but if I had to choose one, I would say 10, with the caveat that it's not a good match.

to be used for military training. But the Wall's main purpose
today is cultural. As one of the largest man-made
structures on Earth, it was granted UNESCO
World Heritage Status in 1987. Originally built to keep
people out of China, the Great Wall now welcomes
millions of visitors each year. In fact, the influx of tourists
has caused the wall to deteriorate, leading the Chinese government
to launch preservation initiatives. It's also often acclaimed as the only
man-made structure visible from space. Unfortunately, that's not at all true. In low Earth orbit,
all sorts of structures, like bridges, highways
and airports are visible, and the Great Wall
is only barely discernible. From the moon, it doesn't stand a chance. But regardless, it's the Earth
we should be studying it from because new sections
are still discovered every few years, branching off from the main body and expanding this remarkable
monument to human achievement.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: True or false: The Great Wall is the only visible man-made structure in space.
Options: A. True, B. False
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What type of pronoun is "I" in a sentence? Options: A. Object pronoun, B. Subject pronoun, C. Reflexive pronoun, D. Intensive pronoun Correct Option: B
Question 2: Which of the following sentences demonstrates the difference between a subject and an object in a sentence? Options: A. "I invited her, but she invited I.", B. "I invited her, but she invited me.", C. "She danced around me, while he shimmied up to me.", D. "Me heard gossip." Correct Option: B
Question 3: What is the main function of "myself" in a sentence? Options: A. To act as a subject pronoun, B. To act as an object pronoun, C. To add emphasis, D. To act as a reflexive pronoun Correct Option: D
Question 4: In the sentence "Please tell Jack or myself," which of the following is the correct pronoun to use? Options: A. I, B. Me, C. Myself, D. They Correct Option: B
Question 5: In which of the following sentences is "myself" used as an intensive pronoun? Options: A. "I consider myself the most important pronoun at this year's party.", B. "Myself heard gossip.", C. "I, myself, have heard others agree.", D. "Me heard gossip." Correct Option: C
Question 6: What is the main difference between "me" and "I" in a sentence? Options: A. "Me" is used for formal writing, while "I" is used for informal writing., B. "Me" is used as a subject pronoun, while "I" is used as an object pronoun., C. "Me" is used as an object pronoun, while "I" is used as a subject pronoun., D. "Me" is used as a reflexive pronoun, while "I" is used as an intensive pronoun. Correct Option: C
Question 7: How can you determine whether to use "I" or "me" in a sentence? Options: A. By temporarily eliminating the other person in the sentence., B. By using a dictionary to look up the definition of the word., C. By using a thesaurus to find a synonym for the word., D. By using a grammar book to look up the rule. Correct Option: A
Question 8: What is the main function of "myself" in the sentence "I consider myself the most important pronoun at this year's party"? Options: A. To add emphasis, B. To act as a subject pronoun, C. To act as an object pronoun, D. To act as a reflexive pronoun Correct Option: D
Question 9: Which of the following sentences is an example of a sentence that uses "myself" as a reflexive pronoun? Options: A. "Myself heard gossip.", B. "I consider myself the most important pronoun at this year's party.", C. "Myself is going to the store.", D. "I, myself, have heard others agree." Correct Option: B
Question 10: What is the main idea of the transcript? Options: A. To explain the difference between "me" and "I" in a sentence., B. To explain the difference between "myself" and "me" in a sentence., C. To explain how to use "myself" in a sentence., D. To explain the main functions of pronouns in a sentence. Correct Option: D

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 19, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Me, myself, and I. You may be tempted to use 
these words interchangeably because they all refer to the same thing, but in fact, each one has a specific role
in a sentence. "I" is a subject pronoun, "me" is an object pronoun, and "myself" is a reflexive
or intensive pronoun. So what does that reveal about
where each word belongs? Let's start with the difference
between subject and object. Imagine the subject 
as the actor in a sentence and the object as the word
that is acted upon. "I invited her but she invited me." The object can also be 
the object of a preposition. "She danced around me, 
while he shimmied up to me." In some languages, like Latin and Russian, most nouns have different forms
that distinguish subjects from objects. However, in English, 
that's only true of pronouns. But so long as you know how to distinguish
subjects from objects, you can figure out what belongs where. And when you encounter 
a more complicated sentence, say one that involves 
multiple subjects or objects, and you're not sure 
whether to use "I" or "me," just temporarily eliminate 
the other person, and once again distinguish 
subject from object. Here's another. You wouldn't say, "Me heard gossip,"
but sub in "I" and you're good to go. Then what about "myself?" This grand character is often substituted
for "me" and "I" because it seems more impressive. "Please tell Jack or myself" 
may sound elegant, but in fact, "me" 
is the right pronoun here. So where should you use "myself"? In its function as a reflexive pronoun, "myself" only works 
if it's the object of a sentence whose subject is "I." "I consider myself the most important
pronoun at this year's party." "Myself" can also add emphasis
as an intensive pronoun. "I, myself, have heard others agree." The sentence works without it, but that extra pronoun gives it oomph. To check if "myself" belongs 
in a sentence, simply ensure that there's also an "I"
that it's reflecting or intensifying. So that's "me," "myself," and "I," ever ready to represent 
you, yourself, and you.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: The pronoun 'I' is:
Options: A. A reflexive pronoun, B. An adjective pronoun, C. An objective pronoun, D. A subject pronoun
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: How do crabs communicate with each other? Options: A. By using a complex dance, B. By waving their claws at each other, C. By changing the color of their skin, D. By making loud noises Correct Option: B
Question 2: What are the four specific qualities often associated with language? Options: A. Discreteness, grammar, productivity, and displacement, B. Discreteness, grammar, creativity, and imagination, C. Discreteness, grammar, productivity, and complexity, D. Discreteness, grammar, displacement, and communication Correct Option: A
Question 3: How do bees use their waggle dance to communicate? Options: A. They use the dance to describe the location and richness of a food source, B. They use the dance to warn other bees of predators, C. They use the dance to signal that they're healthy and ready to mate, D. They use the dance to communicate with other bees about their social hierarchy Correct Option: A
Question 4: What is one example of how a great ape has demonstrated discreteness in communication? Options: A. A chimpanzee named Washoe combined multiple signs into original phrases, like "Please open. Hurry.", B. A gorilla named Coco understood more than 1000 signs and around 2000 words of spoken English, C. A chimpanzee named Bongo used a modified sign language to communicate with humans, D. A gorilla named Koko used a complex dance to communicate with other gorillas Correct Option: A
Question 5: What is an example of how a prairie dog's alarm call indicates the presence of a predator? Options: A. The size, shape, speed, and type of predator, B. The location, richness, and quality of a food source, C. The presence of a rival prairie dog, D. The presence of a human predator and what they are wearing Correct Option: A
Question 6: What is one way in which human language stands out from animal communication? Options: A. Human language is more complex and has more nuances, B. Human language is more limited and has fewer elements, C. Human language is more finite and has fewer possibilities, D. Human language is more powerful and can create an infinite number of messages Correct Option: D
Question 7: What is the significance of the fact that human language can create an infinite number of messages? Options: A. It allows humans to communicate about a wide range of subjects, B. It allows humans to communicate about imaginary things, C. It allows humans to communicate about past, future, and fictional events, D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 8: What is one way in which research on animal communication may continue to reveal more about human language? Options: A. By studying the similarities and differences between human and animal communication, B. By studying the evolution of human language, C. By studying the development of language in children, D. By studying the use of language in different cultures Correct Option: A
Question 9: What is the implication of the fact that human language and animal communication may exist on a continuum? Options: A. It suggests that human language is more complex and nuanced than animal communication, B. It suggests that human language is more limited and finite than animal communication, C. It suggests that human language and animal communication are more similar than previously thought, D. It suggests that human language is more powerful and creative than animal communication Correct Option: C
Question 10: What is one way in which humans can learn from studying animal communication? Options: A. By understanding the similarities and differences between human and animal communication, B. By developing new methods of communication, C. By improving our ability to communicate with animals, D. All of the above Correct Option: D


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 19, Question 5
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Me, myself, and I. You may be tempted to use 
these words interchangeably because they all refer to the same thing, but in fact, each one has a specific role
in a sentence. "I" is a subject pronoun, "me" is an object pronoun, and "myself" is a reflexive
or intensive pronoun. So what does that reveal about
where each word belongs? Let's start with the difference
between subject and object. Imagine the subject 
as the actor in a sentence and the object as the word
that is acted upon. "I invited her but she invited me." The object can also be 
the object of a preposition. "She danced around me, 
while he shimmied up to me." In some languages, like Latin and Russian, most nouns have different forms
that distinguish subjects from objects. However, in English, 
that's only true of pronouns. But so long as you know how to distinguish
subjects from objects, you can figure out what belongs where. And when you encounter 
a more complicated sentence, say one that involves 
multiple subjects or objects, and you're not sure 
whether to use "I" or "me," just temporarily eliminate 
the other person, and once again distinguish 
subject from object. Here's another. You wouldn't say, "Me heard gossip,"
but sub in "I" and you're good to go. Then what about "myself?" This grand character is often substituted
for "me" and "I" because it seems more impressive. "Please tell Jack or myself" 
may sound elegant, but in fact, "me" 
is the right pronoun here. So where should you use "myself"? In its function as a reflexive pronoun, "myself" only works 
if it's the object of a sentence whose subject is "I." "I consider myself the most important
pronoun at this year's party." "Myself" can also add emphasis
as an intensive pronoun. "I, myself, have heard others agree." The sentence works without it, but that extra pronoun gives it oomph. To check if "myself" belongs 
in a sentence, simply ensure that there's also an "I"
that it's reflecting or intensifying. So that's "me," "myself," and "I," ever ready to represent 
you, yourself, and you.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: You should use the word 'myself' wherever you can because it sounds elegant and impressive.
Options: A. True, B. False
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: How do crabs communicate with each other? Options: A. By using a complex dance, B. By waving their claws at each other, C. By changing the color of their skin, D. By making loud noises Correct Option: B

Discreteness, grammar, creativity, and imagination, C. Discreteness, grammar, productivity, and complexity, D. Discreteness, grammar, displacement, and communication Correct Option: A
Question 3: How do bees use their waggle dance to communicate? Options: A. They use the dance to describe the location and richness of a food source, B. They use the dance to warn other bees of predators, C. They use the dance to signal that they're healthy and ready to mate, D. They use the dance to communicate with other bees about their social hierarchy Correct Option: A
Question 4: What is one example of how a great ape has demonstrated discreteness in communication? Options: A. A chimpanzee named Washoe combined multiple signs into original phrases, like "Please open. Hurry.", B. A gorilla named Coco understood more than 1000 signs and around 2000 words of spoken English, C. A chimpanzee named Bongo used a modified sign language to communicate with humans, D. A gorilla named Koko used a complex dance to communicate with other gorillas Correct Option: A
Question 5: What is an example of how a prairie dog's alarm call indicates the presence of a predator? Options: A. The size, shape, speed, and type of predator, B. The location, richness, and quality of a food source, C. The presence of a rival prairie dog, D. The presence of a human predator and what they are wearing Correct Option: A
Question 6: What is one way in which human language stands out from animal communication? Options: A. Human language is more complex and has more nuances, B. Human language is more limited and has fewer elements, C. Human language is more finite and has fewer possibilities, D. Human language is more powerful and can create an infinite number of messages Correct Option: D
Question 7: What is the significance of the fact that human language can create an infinite number of messages? Options: A. It allows humans to communicate about a wide range of subjects, B. It allows humans to communicate about imaginary things, C. It allows humans to communicate about past, future, and fictional events, D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 8: What is one way in which research on animal communication may continue to reveal more about human language? Options: A. By studying the similarities and differences between human and animal communication, B. By studying the evolution of human language, C. By studying the development of language in children, D. By studying the use of language in different cultures Correct Option: A
Question 9: What is the implication of the fact that human language and animal communication may exist on a continuum? Options: A. It suggests that human language is more complex and nuanced than animal communication, B. It suggests that human language is more limited and finite than animal communication, C. It suggests that human language and animal communication are more similar than previously thought, D. It suggests that human language is more powerful and creative than animal communication Correct Option: C
Question 10: What is one way in which humans can learn from studying animal communication? Options: A. By understanding the similarities and differences between human and animal communication, B. By developing new methods of communication, C. By improving our ability to communicate with animals, D. All of the above Correct Option: D

Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 20, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
All animals communicate. Crabs wave their claws at each other
to signal that they're healthy and ready to mate. Cuttlefish use pigmented skin cells
called chromatophores to create patterns on their skin
that act as camouflage or warnings to rivals. Honeybees perform complex dances to let other bees know the location
and quality of a food source. All of these animals have impressive
communication systems, but do they have language? To answer that question, we can look at four specific qualities
that are often associated with language: discreteness, grammar, productivity, and displacement. Discreteness means that there is a set
of individual units, such as sounds or words, that can be combined
to communicate new ideas, like a set of refrigerator poetry magnets
you can rearrange to create different phrases. Grammar provides a system of rules that tells you how to combine 
those individual units. Productivity is the ability 
to use language to create an infinite number of messages. And displacement is the ability 
to talk about things that aren't right in front of you, such as past, future, or fictional events. So, does animal communication exhibit 
any of these qualities? For crabs and cuttlefish, 
the answer is no. They don't combine their signals 
in creative ways. Those signals also don't have to be 
in a grammatical order, and they only communicate 
current conditions, like, "I am healthy," 
or "I am poisonous." But some animals actually do display
some of these properties. Bees use the moves, angle, duration,
and intensity of their waggle dance to describe the location and richness
of a food source. That source is outside the hive, so they exhibit the property 
of displacement. They share that language trait
with prairie dogs, which live in towns of thousands, and are hunted by coyotes, hawks,
badgers, snakes, and humans. Their alarms calls indicate
the predator's size, shape, speed, and, even for human predators,
what the person is wearing and if he's carrying a gun. Great apes, like chimps and gorillas,
are great communicators, too. Some have even learned 
a modified sign language. A chimpanzee named Washoe
demonstrated discreteness by combining multiple signs
into original phrases, like, "Please open. Hurry." Coco, a female gorilla who understands
more than 1000 signs, and around 2000 words of spoken English referred to a beloved kitten 
that had died. In doing so, she displayed displacement, though it's worth noting that the apes
in both of these examples were using a human communication system, not one that appeared 
naturally in the wild. There are many other examples
of sophisticated animal communication, such as in dolphins, which use whistles to identify age, 
location, names, and gender. They can also understand some grammar in a gestural language researchers use
to communicate with them. However, grammar is not seen 
in the dolphin's natural communication. While these communication systems may have some of the qualities 
of language we've identified, none display all four. Even Washoe and Coco's impressive 
abilities are still outpaced by the language skills 
of most three-year-old humans. And animals' topics of conversation
are usually limited. Bees talk about food, prairie dogs talk about predators, and crabs talk about themselves. Human language stands alone due to the powerful combination
of grammar and productivity, on top of discreteness and displacement. The human brain can take 
a finite number of elements and create an infinite number of messages. We can craft and understand 
complex sentences, as well as words that have never
been spoken before. We can use language to communicate
about an endless range of subjects, talk about imaginary things, and even lie. Research continues to reveal more
and more about animal communication. It may turn out that human language
and animal communication aren't entirely different
but exist on a continuum. After all, we are all animals.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Discreteness is one characteristic of human language. Discreteness means:
Options: A. People can talk about topics in the past, in the future, or things not immediately present either temporally or physically, B. People can combine the units of their language (sounds, words, signs) to create, communicate and understand new ideas., C. People use discretion or tact when talking so as to not offend the person or people they are talking to, D. People talk about imaginary or abstract topics, such as "Liberty" and "Love"
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What was the original purpose of the Olympic games in ancient Greece? Options: A. To promote economic growth, B. To celebrate the end of a war, C. To honor the Greek god Zeus and promote athletic excellence, D. To promote unity among Greek cities Correct Option: C
Question 2: Who was the first Olympic champion? Options: A. Orsippus of Megarian, B. Coroebus, C. Homer, D. Zeus Correct Option: B
Question 3: What event was initially part of the Olympic games where competitors wore a full suit of armor? Options: A. The stadion (200-yard dash), B. The pentathlon, C. The pankration, D. The hoplitodromos (hoplite race) Correct Option: D
Question 4: Why did the Christian Roman Emperor Theodosius ban the Olympic games in 391 AD? Options: A. Because they were too expensive, B. Because they were too competitive, C. Because they were pagan practices, D. Because they were too violent Correct Option: C
Question 5: What is the modern Olympic motto? Options: A. Faster, Higher, Stronger, B. Unity, Strength, Victory, C. Excellence, Courage, Friendship, D. Citius, Altius, Fortius Correct Option: D
Question 6: In what year did the modern Olympic games kick off in Athens, Greece? Options: A. 776 BC, B. 720 BC, C. 391 AD, D. 1896 Correct Option: D
Question 7: Which literary works feature the Olympic games? Options: A. The Odyssey, B. The Aeneid, C. The Iliad, D. Both B and C Correct Option: D
Question 8: What is the significance of the Olympic games in modern times? Options: A. To promote economic growth, B. To promote cultural exchange, C. To bring international world-class athletes together, D. To showcase the greatest show of sporting excellence Correct Option: D
Question 9: What was the main reason for the decline of the Olympic games in ancient Greece? Options: A. Because they were too violent, B. Because they were too expensive, C. Because they were banned by the Christian Roman Emperor Theodosius, D. Because they were too competitive Correct Option: C
Question 10: What is the impact of the Olympic games on international relations? Options: A. It promotes conflict and tension among nations, B. It promotes economic growth and development, C. It has no impact on international relations, D. It promotes unity and cooperation among nations Correct Option: D


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
None of the generated MCQs match the ground truth MCQ. The generated MCQs appear to be related to the Olympic games, whereas the ground truth MCQ is related to the concept of discreteness in human language.

However, if I had to choose the most similar generated MCQ based on the question format and style, I would say that none of the generated MCQs are similar to the ground truth MCQ.

But if you want me to choose an index, I would say -1 (or None) as there is no matching generated MCQ.

Bees and humans follow grammatical principles when communicating, D. Bees and humans can rearrange individual units of their communication to communicate new ideas

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 20, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
All animals communicate. Crabs wave their claws at each other
to signal that they're healthy and ready to mate. Cuttlefish use pigmented skin cells

a modified sign language. A chimpanzee named Washoe
demonstrated discreteness by combining multiple signs
into original phrases, like, "Please open. Hurry." Coco, a female gorilla who understands
more than 1000 signs, and around 2000 words of spoken English referred to a beloved kitten 
that had died. In doing so, she displayed displacement, though it's worth noting that the apes
in both of these examples were using a human communication system, not one that appeared 
naturally in the wild. There are many other examples
of sophisticated animal communication, such as in dolphins, which use whistles to identify age, 
location, names, and gender. They can also understand some grammar in a gestural language researchers use
to communicate with them. However, grammar is not seen 
in the dolphin's natural communication. While these communication systems may have some of the qualities 
of language we've identified, none display all four. Even Washoe and Coco's impressive 
abilities are still outpaced by the language skills 
of most three-year-old humans. And animals' topics of conversation
are usually limited. Bees talk about food, prairie dogs talk about predators, and crabs talk about themselves. Human language stands alone due to the powerful combination
of grammar and productivity, on top of discreteness and displacement. The human brain can take 
a finite number of elements and create an infinite number of messages. We can craft and understand 
complex sentences, as well as words that have never
been spoken before. We can use language to communicate
about an endless range of subjects, talk about imaginary things, and even lie. Research continues to reveal more
and more about animal communication. It may turn out that human language
and animal communication aren't entirely different
but exist on a continuum. After all, we are all animals.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: "Productivity" refers to:
Options: A. An animal's ability to produce effective messages for survival, B. The ability by both humans and animals to talk about abstract topics, C. The unique human capability to use language to create an infinite number of messages, D. The ability for any animal to produce and receive signals from others
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What was the original purpose of the Olympic games in ancient Greece? Options: A. To promote economic growth, B. To celebrate the end of a war, C. To honor the Greek god Zeus and promote athletic excellence, D. To promote unity among Greek cities Correct Option: C
Question 2: Who was the first Olympic champion? Options: A. Orsippus of Megarian, B. Coroebus, C. Homer, D. Zeus Correct Option: B
Question 3: What event was initially part of the Olympic games where competitors wore a full suit of armor? Options: A. The stadion (200-yard dash), B. The pentathlon, C. The pankration, D. The hoplitodromos (hoplite race) Correct Option: D
Question 4: Why did the Christian Roman Emperor Theodosius ban the Olympic games in 391 AD? Options: A. Because they were too expensive, B. Because they were too competitive, C. Because they were pagan practices, D. Because they were too violent Correct Option: C
Question 5: What is the modern Olympic motto? Options: A. Faster, Higher, Stronger, B. Unity, Strength, Victory, C. Excellence, Courage, Friendship, D. Citius, Altius, Fortius Correct Option: D
Question 6: In what year did the modern Olympic games kick off in Athens, Greece? Options: A. 776 BC, B. 720 BC, C. 391 AD, D. 1896 Correct Option: D
Question 7: Which literary works feature the Olympic games? Options: A. The Odyssey, B. The Aeneid, C. The Iliad, D. Both B and C Correct Option: D
Question 8: What is the significance of the Olympic games in modern times? Options: A. To promote economic growth, B. To promote cultural exchange, C. To bring international world-class athletes together, D. To showcase the greatest show of sporting excellence Correct Option: D
Question 9: What was the main reason for the decline of the Olympic games in ancient Greece? Options: A. Because they were too violent, B. Because they were too expensive, C. Because they were banned by the Christian Roman Emperor Theodosius, D. Because they were too competitive Correct Option: C

It has no impact on international relations, D. It promotes unity and cooperation among nations Correct Option: D

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 20, Question 5
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
All animals communicate. Crabs wave their claws at each other
to signal that they're healthy and ready to mate. Cuttlefish use pigmented skin cells
called chromatophores to create patterns on their skin
that act as camouflage or warnings to rivals. Honeybees perform complex dances to let other bees know the location
and quality of a food source. All of these animals have impressive
communication systems, but do they have language? To answer that question, we can look at four specific qualities
that are often associated with language: discreteness, grammar, productivity, and displacement. Discreteness means that there is a set
of individual units, such as sounds or words, that can be combined
to communicate new ideas, like a set of refrigerator poetry magnets
you can rearrange to create different phrases. Grammar provides a system of rules that tells you how to combine 
those individual units. Productivity is the ability 
to use language to create an infinite number of messages. And displacement is the ability 
to talk about things that aren't right in front of you, such as past, future, or fictional events. So, does animal communication exhibit 
any of these qualities? For crabs and cuttlefish, 
the answer is no. They don't combine their signals 
in creative ways. Those signals also don't have to be 
in a grammatical order, and they only communicate 
current conditions, like, "I am healthy," 
or "I am poisonous." But some animals actually do display
some of these properties. Bees use the moves, angle, duration,
and intensity of their waggle dance to describe the location and richness
of a food source. That source is outside the hive, so they exhibit the property 
of displacement. They share that language trait
with prairie dogs, which live in towns of thousands, and are hunted by coyotes, hawks,
badgers, snakes, and humans. Their alarms calls indicate
the predator's size, shape, speed, and, even for human predators,
what the person is wearing and if he's carrying a gun. Great apes, like chimps and gorillas,
are great communicators, too. Some have even learned 
a modified sign language. A chimpanzee named Washoe
demonstrated discreteness by combining multiple signs
into original phrases, like, "Please open. Hurry." Coco, a female gorilla who understands
more than 1000 signs, and around 2000 words of spoken English referred to a beloved kitten 
that had died. In doing so, she displayed displacement, though it's worth noting that the apes
in both of these examples were using a human communication system, not one that appeared 
naturally in the wild. There are many other examples
of sophisticated animal communication, such as in dolphins, which use whistles to identify age, 
location, names, and gender. They can also understand some grammar in a gestural language researchers use
to communicate with them. However, grammar is not seen 
in the dolphin's natural communication. While these communication systems may have some of the qualities 
of language we've identified, none display all four. Even Washoe and Coco's impressive 
abilities are still outpaced by the language skills 
of most three-year-old humans. And animals' topics of conversation
are usually limited. Bees talk about food, prairie dogs talk about predators, and crabs talk about themselves. Human language stands alone due to the powerful combination
of grammar and productivity, on top of discreteness and displacement. The human brain can take 
a finite number of elements and create an infinite number of messages. We can craft and understand 
complex sentences, as well as words that have never
been spoken before. We can use language to communicate
about an endless range of subjects, talk about imaginary things, and even lie. Research continues to reveal more
and more about animal communication. It may turn out that human language
and animal communication aren't entirely different
but exist on a continuum. After all, we are all animals.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Great apes like Koko and Washoe:
Options: A. Can talk about abstract topics such as liberty and love, B. Use grammatical rules when communicating just like human children, C. Do not exhibit the same grammatical capabilities as human children, D. Can use sign language fluently as a deaf person would
Correct Option: C

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 21, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Thousands of years in the making, what began as part of a religious festival
honoring the Greek god Zeus in the rural Greek town of Olympia has today become the greatest show
of sporting excellence on Earth. The inception date in 776 BC became the basis 
for the Greek's earliest calendar, where time was marked 
in four-year increments called olympiads. What could it be? Why, it's the Olympic games, of course. Competition fosters excellence,
or so thought the Ancient Greeks. In addition to sporting events, contests were held for music, 
singing, and poetry. You can read about them all yourself
in classical literary works, like Homer's "Iliad" 
and Virgil's "Aeneid." Even mythical heroes appreciate 
a good contest every now and then, wouldn't you say? For the first thirteen games, the Ancient Greek Olympics featured
just one event, the two hundred yard dash. But over time, new exciting contests, like boxing, chariot and mule racing, and even a footrace where the competitors
wore a full suit of armor enticed many hopeful champions
into the Olympic stadium. The combined running, jumping, wrestling, javelin throwing, and hurling the discus events known as the pentathlon
inspired world-class competition, and the pankration, a no holds barred fight where only
biting and eye-gouging were prohibited, ensured the toughest men were victorious. And victorious they were. Nobody tops the local baker Coroebus, who 776 BC became the very first
Olympic champion. And we'll never forget Orsippus of Megara, the 720 BC Olympic victor tore away
his loincloth so he could race unimpeded, inaugurating the Ancient Greek tradition
of competing in the nude. Now there's a winning streak,
if ever we've seen one. But all good things must end. In 391 AD, the Christian Roman Emperor
Theodosius banned pagan practices, so the world soon bid a fond farewell
to the Olympic games. But just like those early 
pankration athletes, you can't keep a good one down, and 1500 years later in 1896, the modern Olympic games
kicked off in Athens, Greece. Today, the Summer and Winter Olympics bring international world-class
athletes together by the thousands, uniting fans by the billions for 
the world's foremost sporting competition. Citius, Altius, Fortius. Three cheers for the Olympics.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What was the date of the first Olympics?
Options: A. 1000 BC, B. 776 BC, C. 1066 AD
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: **Knowledge**: What is the main obstacle that the group must overcome to escape? Options: A. A massive zombie horde, B. A treacherous rope bridge, C. A lack of time to cross the bridge, D. A broken lantern Correct Option: C
Question 2: **Comprehension**: Who is the slowest person in the group and how long does it take them to cross the bridge? Options: A. The lab assistant, 2 minutes, B. The professor, 10 minutes, C. The janitor, 5 minutes, D. The narrator, 1 minute Correct Option: B
Question 3: **Application**: What is the most efficient way to have everyone cross the bridge, given the constraints of the problem? Options: A. Have the two fastest people cross together and then return to help the slower ones, B. Have the two slowest people cross together and then return to help the faster ones, C. Have everyone cross the bridge together at the same time, D. Have the narrator and the lab assistant cross the bridge alone Correct Option: B
Question 4: **Analysis**: Why is it important for the group to minimize the time wasted by the two slowest people? Options: A. Because they are the only ones who can hold the lantern, B. Because they are the only ones who can see in the dark, C. Because they are the only ones who can cross the bridge quickly, D. Because having them cross together allows for more efficient use of time Correct Option: D
Question 5: **Synthesis**: What is the key to solving this problem, according to the narrator? Options: A. Having the two fastest people cross together and then return to help the slower ones, B. Having the two slowest people cross together and then return to help the faster ones, C. Having everyone cross the bridge together at the same time, D. Having the narrator and the lab assistant cross the bridge alone Correct Option: B
Question 6: **Evaluation**: Do you think the narrator's plan is the best way to solve this problem, or is there a better solution? Options: A. Yes, it is the best way, B. No, there is a better solution, C. Maybe, it depends on the situation, D. I don't know Correct Option: A
Question 7: **Knowledge**: Who is the narrator of the story? Options: A. The lab assistant, B. The professor, C. The janitor, D. One of the group members (the narrator is not explicitly stated to be one of the group members, so this option is incorrect) Correct Option: D
Question 8: **Comprehension**: What is the consequence of the zombies catching up to the group? Options: A. They will be trapped on the bridge, B. They will have to return to the starting point, C. They will be attacked by the zombies, D. They will have to wait for help to arrive Correct Option: C
Question 9: **Application**: What should the group do if they are unable to cross the bridge in time? Options: A. Try to find another way to cross the bridge, B. Wait for help to arrive, C. Attempt to fight off the zombies, D. Give up and accept their fate Correct Option: A
Question 10: **Evaluation**: Do you think the narrator's plan is realistic, or is it too optimistic? Options: A. It is realistic, B. It is too optimistic, C. It depends on the situation, D. I don't know Correct Option: A


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
None of the generated MCQs match the ground truth MCQ in terms of question intent, options, and content. The generated MCQs appear to be related to a completely different topic, involving a group of people trying to escape from zombies by crossing a bridge.

However, if I had to choose the most similar generated MCQ based on the fact that it is a "Knowledge" type question, I would say that Question 1 is the closest match. But please note that the question intent, options, and content are still completely different from the ground truth MCQ.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 21, Question 3

**Transcript**:
Thousands of years in the making, what began as part of a religious festival
honoring the Greek god Zeus in the rural Greek town of Olympia has today become the greatest show
of sporting excellence on Earth. The inception date in 776 BC became the basis 
for the Greek's earliest calendar, where time was marked 
in four-year increments called olympiads. What could it be? Why, it's the Olympic games, of course. Competition fosters excellence,
or so thought the Ancient Greeks. In addition to sporting events, contests were held for music, 
singing, and poetry. You can read about them all yourself
in classical literary works, like Homer's "Iliad" 
and Virgil's "Aeneid." Even mythical heroes appreciate 
a good contest every now and then, wouldn't you say? For the first thirteen games, the Ancient Greek Olympics featured
just one event, the two hundred yard dash. But over time, new exciting contests, like boxing, chariot and mule racing, and even a footrace where the competitors
wore a full suit of armor enticed many hopeful champions
into the Olympic stadium. The combined running, jumping, wrestling, javelin throwing, and hurling the discus events known as the pentathlon
inspired world-class competition, and the pankration, a no holds barred fight where only
biting and eye-gouging were prohibited, ensured the toughest men were victorious. And victorious they were. Nobody tops the local baker Coroebus, who 776 BC became the very first

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 21, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Thousands of years in the making, what began as part of a religious festival
honoring the Greek god Zeus in the rural Greek town of Olympia has today become the greatest show
of sporting excellence on Earth. The inception date in 776 BC became the basis 
for the Greek's earliest calendar, where time was marked 
in four-year increments called olympiads. What could it be? Why, it's the Olympic games, of course. Competition fosters excellence,
or so thought the Ancient Greeks. In addition to sporting events, contests were held for music, 
singing, and poetry. You can read about them all yourself
in classical literary works, like Homer's "Iliad" 
and Virgil's "Aeneid." Even mythical heroes appreciate 
a good contest every now and then, wouldn't you say? For the first thirteen games, the Ancient Greek Olympics featured
just one event, the two hundred yard dash. But over time, new exciting contests, like boxing, chariot and mule racing, and even a footrace where the competitors
wore a full suit of armor enticed many hopeful champions
into the Olympic stadium. The combined running, jumping, wrestling, javelin throwing, and hurling the discus events known as the pentathlon
inspired world-class competition, and the pankration, a no holds barred fight where only
biting and eye-gouging were prohibited, ensured the toughest men were victorious. And victorious they were. Nobody tops the local baker Coroebus, who 776 BC became the very first
Olympic champion. And we'll never forget Orsippus of Megara, the 720 BC Olympic victor tore away
his loincloth so he could race unimpeded, inaugurating the Ancient Greek tradition
of competing in the nude. Now there's a winning streak,
if ever we've seen one. But all good things must end. In 391 AD, the Christian Roman Emperor
Theodosius banned pagan practices, so the world soon bid a fond farewell
to the Olympic games. But just like those early 
pankration athletes, you can't keep a good one down, and 1500 years later in 1896, the modern Olympic games
kicked off in Athens, Greece. Today, the Summer and Winter Olympics bring international world-class
athletes together by the thousands, uniting fans by the billions for 
the world's foremost sporting competition. Citius, Altius, Fortius. Three cheers for the Olympics.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Which Roman emperor banned the Olympics?
Options: A. Nero, B. Diocletian, C. Theodosius
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: **Knowledge**: What is the main obstacle that the group must overcome to escape? Options: A. A massive zombie horde, B. A treacherous rope bridge, C. A lack of time to cross the bridge, D. A broken lantern Correct Option: C
Question 2: **Comprehension**: Who is the slowest person in the group and how long does it take them to cross the bridge? Options: A. The lab assistant, 2 minutes, B. The professor, 10 minutes, C. The janitor, 5 minutes, D. The narrator, 1 minute Correct Option: B
Question 3: **Application**: What is the most efficient way to have everyone cross the bridge, given the constraints of the problem? Options: A. Have the two fastest people cross together and then return to help the slower ones, B. Have the two slowest people cross together and then return to help the faster ones, C. Have everyone cross the bridge together at the same time, D. Have the narrator and the lab assistant cross the bridge alone Correct Option: B
Question 4: **Analysis**: Why is it important for the group to minimize the time wasted by the two slowest people? Options: A. Because they are the only ones who can hold the lantern, B. Because they are the only ones who can see in the dark, C. Because they are the only ones who can cross the bridge quickly, D. Because having them cross together allows for more efficient use of time Correct Option: D
Question 5: **Synthesis**: What is the key to solving this problem, according to the narrator? Options: A. Having the two fastest people cross together and then return to help the slower ones, B. Having the two slowest people cross together and then return to help the faster ones, C. Having everyone cross the bridge together at the same time, D. Having the narrator and the lab assistant cross the bridge alone Correct Option: B
Question 6: **Evaluation**: Do you think the narrator's plan is the best way to solve this problem, or is there a better solution? Options: A. Yes, it is the best way, B. No, there is a better solution, C. Maybe, it depends on the situation, D. I don't know Correct Option: A
Question 7: **Knowledge**: Who is the narrator of the story? Options: A. The lab assistant, B. The professor, C. The janitor, D. One of the group members (the narrator is not explicitly stated to be one of the group members, so this option is incorrect) Correct Option: D
Question 8: **Comprehension**: What is the consequence of the zombies catching up to the group? Options: A. They will be trapped on the bridge, B. They will have to return to the starting point, C. They will be attacked by the zombies, D. They will have to wait for help to arrive Correct Option: C
Question 9: **Application**: What should the group do if they are unable to cross the bridge in time? Options: A. Try to find another way to cross the bridge, B. Wait for help to arrive, C. Attempt to fight off the zombies, D. Give up and accept their fate Correct Option: A
Question 10: **Evaluation**: Do you think the narrator's plan is realistic, or is it too optimistic? Options: A. It is realistic, B. It is too optimistic, C. It depends on the situation, D. I don't know Correct Option: A


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 22, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Taking that internship 
in a remote mountain lab might not have been the best idea. Pulling that lever with the skull symbol
just to see what it did probably wasn't so smart, either, but now is not the time for regrets because you need to get away
from these mutant zombies fast. With you are the janitor, 
the lab assistant, and the old professor. You've gotten a headstart,
but there's only one way to safety: across an old rope bridge
spanning a massive gorge. You can dash across in a minute, while the lab assistant takes two minutes. The janitor is a bit slower
and needs five minutes, and the professor takes
a whole ten minutes, holding onto the ropes 
every step of the way. By the professor's calculations, the zombies will catch up to you
in just over 17 minutes, so you only have that much time
to get everyone across and cut the ropes. Unfortunately, the bridge can only hold
two people at a time. To make matters worse, it's so dark out that you can barely see, and the old lantern you grabbed on
your way only illuminates a tiny area. Can you figure out a way
to have everyone escape in time? Remember: no more than two people
can cross the bridge together, anyone crossing must either
hold the lantern or stay right next to it, and any of you can safely wait in the dark
on either side of the gorge. Most importantly, everyone must be
safely across before the zombies arrive. Otherwise, the first zombie could step on
the bridge while people are still on it. Finally, there are no tricks to use here. You can't swing across, use the bridge as a raft, or befriend the zombies. Pause the video now 
if you want to figure it out for yourself! Answer in: 3 Answer in: 2 Answer in: 1 At first it might seem 
like no matter what you do, you're just a minute or two short of time,
but there is a way. The key is to minimize the time wasted
by the two slowest people by having them cross together. And because you'll need to make
a couple of return trips with the lantern, you'll want to have the fastest people
available to do so. So, you and the lab assistant quickly
run across with the lantern, though you have to slow down 
a bit to match her pace. After two minutes, both of you are across, and you, as the quickest, 
run back with the lantern. Only three minutes have passed. So far, so good. Now comes the hard part. The professor and the janitor take
the lantern and cross together. This takes them ten minutes since the janitor has to slow down 
for the old professor who keeps muttering that he probably shouldn't 
have given the zombies night vision. By the time they're across,
there are only four minutes left, and you're still stuck
on the wrong side of the bridge. But remember, the lab assistant
has been waiting on the other side, and she's the second fastest of the group. So she grabs the lantern 
from the professor and runs back across to you. Now with only two minutes left,
the two of you make the final crossing. As you step on the far side of the gorge, you cut the ropes 
and collapse the bridge behind you, just in the nick of time. Maybe next summer, 
you'll just stick to the library.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Who is the slowest out of the four people in the riddle?
Options: A. You, B. The professor, C. The assistant, D. The janitor
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: Approximately when did the first cetaceans enter the water as large predators with sharp teeth? Options: A. 50 million years ago, B. 55 million years ago, C. 60 million years ago, D. 65 million years ago Correct Option: B
Question 2: Which group of dolphins practices a sophisticated form of cooperation to hunt fish in Florida? Options: A. The Dolphin Sponge Club, B. The Net-Maker Dolphins, C. A group of Florida dolphins, D. A group of dolphins in another region Correct Option: C
Question 3: How do dolphins pass down their communication methods and other skills from generation to generation? Options: A. Through written documents, B. Through verbal instructions, C. Through a combination of social learning, imitation, and mother-to-daughter transmission, D. Through a single method Correct Option: C
Question 4: What is the name of the dolphin group off the Australian coast that has learned how to cover their rostrums with sponges when rooting in sharp corals? Options: A. The Dolphin Sponge-Dwelling Dolphins, B. The Dolphin Sponge Club, C. A group of dolphins, D. The Florida Dolphins Correct Option: B
Question 5: What main elements of human language have dolphins demonstrated they can process? Options: A. Only symbols that stand for objects, B. Only syntax that governs how symbols are structured, C. Both symbols that stand for objects and syntax that governs how they are structured, D. Neither symbols nor syntax Correct Option: C
Question 6: What does dolphins' ability to pass the mirror test indicate? Options: A. Physical self-awareness, B. Metacognition, C. Empathy, D. Altruism Correct Option: A
Question 7: What is an example of complex social behavior demonstrated by dolphins? Options: A. Cooperative hunting, B. Complex communication, C. Tool use, D. Social learning Correct Option: A
Question 8: In a study, how did dolphins process two sounds and indicate a same, different, or uncertain response? Options: A. By indicating uncertainty more often with easy trials, B. By indicating uncertainty more often with difficult trials, C. By not showing any uncertainty, D. By not demonstrating metacognition Correct Option: B
Question 9: What is the ultimate question that may be asked when considering all the evidence about dolphins? Options: A. Whether dolphins are intelligent and complex beings, B. Whether humans can empathize with dolphins enough to keep them safe and free, C. Whether dolphins are capable of language comprehension, D. None of the above Correct Option: B
Question 10: In a study, how did dolphins' metacognition ability indicate their confidence in their knowledge? Options: A. They were more confident with difficult trials, B. They indicated uncertainty more often with difficult trials, C. They showed no difference in confidence between easy and difficult trials, D. They did not demonstrate metacognition Correct Option: B
Question 11: What is an example of dolphins' empathetic behavior? Options: A. Helping injured individuals, B. Mourning their dead, C. Both A and B, D. Neither A nor B Correct Option: C
Question 12: What is the name of the group of dolphins that carries humans to the surface to breathe? Options: A. The Dolphin Sponge Club, B. The Net-Maker Dolphins, C. A group of dolphins, D. There is no specific group mentioned in the transcript Correct Option: C
Question 13: Approximately how many different species of cetaceans exist? Options: A. 50, B. 86, C. 100, D. 150 Correct Option: B
Question 14: What is the name of the group of cetaceans that survived the shift in ocean temperatures about 35 million years ago? Options: A. Odontocetes, B. Mysticetes, C. Both A and B, D. Neither A nor B Correct Option: A
Question 15: What is the term used to describe the brain size compared to the average for a cetacean's body size? Options: A. Encephalization quotient, B. Brain-to-body ratio, C. Both A and B, D. Neither A nor B Correct Option: A


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

to have everyone escape in time? Remember: no more than two people
can cross the bridge together, anyone crossing must either
hold the lantern or stay right next to it, and any of you can safely wait in the dark
on either side of the gorge. Most importantly, everyone must be
safely across before the zombies arrive. Otherwise, the first zombie could step on
the bridge while people are still on it. Finally, there are no tricks to use here. You can't swing across, use the bridge as a raft, or befriend the zombies. Pause the video now 
if you want to figure it out for yourself! Answer in: 3 Answer in: 2 Answer in: 1 At first it might seem 
like no matter what you do, you're just a minute or two short of time,
but there is a way. The key is to minimize the time wasted
by the two slowest people by having them cross together. And because you'll need to make
a couple of return trips with the lantern, you'll want to have the fastest people
available to do so. So, you and the lab assistant quickly
run across with the lantern, though you have to slow down 
a bit to match her pace. After two minutes, both of you are across, and you, as the quickest, 
run back with the lantern. Only three minutes have passed. So far, so good. Now comes the hard part. The professor and the janitor take
the lantern and cross together. This takes them ten minutes since the janitor has to slow down 
for the old professor who keeps muttering that he probably shouldn't 
have given the zombies night vision. By the time they're across,
there are only four minutes left, and you're still stuck
on the wrong side of the bridge. But remember, the lab assistant
has been waiting on the other side, and she's the second fastest of the group. So she grabs the lantern 
from the professor and runs back across to you. Now with only two minutes left,
the two of you make the final crossing. As you step on the far side of the gorge, you cut the ropes 
and collapse the bridge behind you, just in the nick of time. Maybe next summer, 
you'll just stick to the library.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Why does everyone crossing the bridge have to stay together?
Options: A. It's dark and there's only one lantern, B. Everyone is too scared to be left alone, C. The footing is unstable and you have to hold on toe ach other, D. You have to be ready to defend yourselves if the zombies catch up
Correct Option: A

**Transcript**:
Taking that internship 
in a remote mountain lab might not have been the best idea. Pulling that lever with the skull symbol
just to see what it did probably wasn't so smart, either, but now is not the time for regrets because you need to get away
from these mutant zombies fast. With you are the janitor, 
the lab assistant, and the old professor. You've gotten a headstart,
but there's only one way to safety: across an old rope bridge
spanning a massive gorge. You can dash across in a minute, while the lab assistant takes two minutes. The janitor is a bit slower
and needs five minutes, and the professor takes
a whole ten minutes, holding onto the ropes 
every step of the way. By the professor's calculations, the zombies will catch up to you
in just over 17 minutes, so you only have that much time
to get everyone across and cut the ropes. Unfortunately, the bridge can only hold
two people at a time. To make matters worse, it's so dark out that you can barely see, and the old lantern you grabbed on
your way only illuminates a tiny area. Can you figure out a way
to have everyone escape in time? Remember: no more than two people
can cross the bridge together, anyone crossing must either
hold the lantern or stay right next to it, and any of you can safely wait in the dark
on either side of the gorge. Most importantly, everyone must be
safely across before the zombies arrive. Otherwise, the first zombie could step on
the bridge while people are still on it. Finally, there are no tricks to use here. You can't swing across, use the bridge as a raft, or befriend the zombies. Pause the video now 
if you want to figure it out for yourself! Answer in: 3 Answer in: 2 Answer in: 1 At first it might seem
